Q1:
Hiya! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, we‚Äôll explore healthy and sustainable eating together.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned loads along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I‚Äôll share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together, have you got any favourite ones?
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save loads of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back! Brilliant, with small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small; for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Do you know how much that helps?
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5:
Fibre is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and its only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fibre in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.

Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon, yeah?
Q6: 80% of young people think living sustainably is really important for their happiness. And 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle, yeah? Brilliant to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, we all can do something to help, you know? Like, we can try the plant-based options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. üòÑ

I'm excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if any of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
Reducing meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles.

Brilliant, having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Any tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people cos we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, lets look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

Do you know which foods are especially harmful for the climate? Hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô.
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. Ok, thats great. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Veggies and fruits have these brilliant plant things that help our brain be healthy and work well. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra bits each week, can boost our mood and make us happier. No limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! You could challenge yourself, your mates, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with a cheeky cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming, it's why 80% of the Amazon rainforest is gone, you know? Farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if there were no trees left here!!! Brilliant, by eating less meat, like veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference. If you eat with others, you can set an example, inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

To make it more fun, you could also chat with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together, what do you think?
Q3: So, here's the thing, if we cut down on our meat intake, we can save a ton of CO2, right? Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it's like driving a car from London to China and back! Isn't that crazy? With small changes like this, everyone can do their part for the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let's start small, maybe try eating meat just once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. What do you think?
Q4: You know, over 70% of farm animals in the UK are stuck on factory farms just to keep prices low. Imagine a chicken having only the space of a laptop to move around, it's like living under a staircase like Harry Potter, forever! üòî These farms keep running because we buy their stuff. But if we choose to eat less meat or go for plant-based options when we can, we're telling them to improve conditions for those animals.
Q5:
So, what's the deal with fiber? It's super important for our stomachs, right? And guess what, you can only find it in plants, not animal foods. When we load up on fiber, we stay full longer and have way more energy for the school day. No more of that tired feeling after lunch, you know?

Changing habits, like what we eat, can be a bit tricky at first. But hey, why not start with something easy? Like trying more plant-based lunches at school. That way, you'll feel more energetic and ready to tackle the afternoon.
Q6:
So, 80% of young people think living sustainably is super important for their happiness, right? And like, 77% are down to try meat alternatives for that sustainable life.

Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China and back! With little changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change right now without waiting for others! Let's start small; like, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5:
Fiber is really important to keep our stomachs healthy, and it's only in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, no more tired feeling after lunch.

Changing what we eat can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be trying more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people think living sustainably is really important for their happiness. And 77% say they'd choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle. It's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. Like, we can try the plant-based food in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. I'm excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
Cutting down on meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really help with acne ‚Äì like, up to 87% less for young people. Eating lots of vegetables and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles.

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there any tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If we all ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11:
Veggies and fruits have stuff that's good for our brain and helps it work better. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra bits a week, can boost our mood and make us happier. 

There's no limit to how many plants we can eat, it's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your mum and dad to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is why 80% of the Amazon rainforest is gone, farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if there were no trees left here! By eating less meat, like picking veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without much change. If you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

i am excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. some of my favorite celebrities eat vegan, like lewis hamilton, billie eilish, and ariana grande. others, like harry styles and lionel messi, they avoid animal products for the most part.
i also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. it looks like we'll have lots of options in future!

reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help with acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.

i see, having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. when do you usually buy food during your day? are there tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?

if everyone ate less animal foods, co2 from food production would drop by 68%. just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.
i see, climate change will mostly affect us young people cause we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

most pigs and chickens in the uk, they kept indoors whole lives, never see sunlight. animals can't go outside, they more stressed, scientists say, way less happy.

Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people 'cause we'll see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can‚Äôt go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier. There‚Äôs no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12:
Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!

By eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1: Hey there! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I‚Äôll be exploring healthy and sustainable eating with you. A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet. Stay tuned, as I‚Äôll be sharing lots of interesting science facts and giving you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables have important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: You know, if we cut down on the meat we eat, it can save a lot of CO2, which is a big deal for climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it's like driving a car from London to China and back! Isn't that crazy? With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change right now, no need to wait for others! Let's start small, for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. What do you think?
Q4: Did you know that more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap? On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. But if we choose to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals. What do you think?
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch. Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6:
80% of young people think that living sustainably is really important for their happiness. And 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.

I like that our generation is on the same page about this. Even if we're not going full vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hey! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, we'll explore healthy and sustainable eating.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don't think we all need to go completely vegan. But being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, I‚Äôll share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: fruits and veggies are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. for instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. to make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3:
Cutting down meat can save loads of CO2, which causes climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of daily for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving from London to China and back!

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let‚Äôs start small, like trying to eat meat just once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5:
fiber's really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. when we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoids that tired feeling after lunch.

changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe living sustainably is crucial for happiness. & 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives for that sustainable life. nice to see our generation on the same page with this. even if we're not going full vegan, we all can do something. like trying plant-based options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hey! nice to see more people choosing plant-based eating. some of my fav celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, tend to avoid animal products. I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! why not see if some of your fav celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
Cutting down meat, dairy, sugary foods really helps with acne, up to 87% less for young folks. Eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, even stops wrinkles.

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food? Any tasty plant-based options you could try next time?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people 'cause we'll see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that's worst for the climate rhymes with 'wow').
Q10: Most pigs & chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed & scientists say, much less happy. We may not change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables & meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, & burgers) instead of animal meat. That's the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11:
Veggies and fruits got helpful stuff that's good for our brain, helps it work well. Just add a few more veggies, like three extra servings a week, can boost mood, make us happier.

No limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! Could challenge yourself, friends, or parents to have more plant-based meals some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).

Animal farming is why the Amazon rainforest is gone by 80%, farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if there were zero trees left here!

By eating less meat (like picking veggie burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without much change. If you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire friends and classmates to be mindful about their food choices too.

Q3:

Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals, sounds good?
Q5: Fiber is super important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and you only find it in plants, not animal foods. When we've got enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, no more of that tired feeling after lunch. Changing habits like what we eat can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be trying more plant-based lunches at school, makes you feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet, ya feel me?

Stay tuned, 'cause I‚Äôma share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits n veggies got important stuff like vitamins, minerals, antioxidants, ya know? They help us fight diseases. Like, people who eat mostly plant stuff were 39% less likely to get Covid n have fewer hospital visits. Nah, for real! Every time we buy food, we decide what goes in our bodies. Make it fun, talk with friends at lunch, try some plant-based stuff together. üí™
Q3:
I think if we cut down on meat, we can save lots of CO2, ya know? Like, if we eat meat every other day for a year, it's like driving from London to China and back! üöóüåè

We all can help the environment with small changes, no need to wait for others. Let's start small, like having meat once a day instead of every meal. üëå
Q4:
More than 70% of farm animals in the UK be raised on factory farms, just to keep animal stuff cheap. On these farms, a chicken got only 'bout the space of a laptop, so hardly any room to move, ya feel me? It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for ya whole life. 

Factory farms keep going 'cause people buy their stuff. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals, nah mean?
Q5: Fiber is real important for our stomachs, ya know? It's only in plants, not animal stuff. When we got enough fiber, we stay full longer and got more energy for school, no more tired after lunch. Changing habits, like what we eat, can be tricky. Easy way to start is try more plant lunches at school, feel more ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people think living sustainably is hella important for happiness. And 77% say they'd choose meat alternatives for that sustainable life. Nah, it's good to see our generation agrees on this. Even if we ain't trying to be full vegan, each of us can do something to help. Like, we can try the plant-based stuff in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. üëç

I'm excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my faves like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande eat vegan. Others like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! üå±

Why not see if some of your faves also eat plant-based? ü§î
Q8:
Cutting down on meat, dairy, and sugary stuff can like, really help with acne. Young people saw up to 87% less acne, ya know? Eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. üçéü•¶

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more of that good stuff. When do You usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try next time? ü§î
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change. üôå

Climate change gonna mostly affect us young people 'cause we gonna see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10:
Most pigs and chickens in the UK be kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside be more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. 

We may not be able to change how animals be treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This the quickest way to help make animals' lives better, nah mean?
Q11: Veggies and fruits got helpful stuff that support our brain health, make it work good. Just add a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) and it can boost our mood, make us feel happier. Nah, there's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is why 80% of the Amazon rainforest is gone, farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as the UK and Ireland got combined. Imagine if there weren't a single tree left here! Nah, we can make a difference by eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch. If you eat with others, you can set an example, inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices. I think it makes a difference, ya know? ü§î

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based? ü§î

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: hey! thanks for following along for the first week. mmmh...I'm excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. oooh, and I see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. it looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: mmmh...so reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne - like up to 87% less acne in young people. And eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles. oooh, so having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
mmmh...If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Oooh, so climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

okay. and you can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: mmmh...most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. I don't think we can change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better, don't you think?

oooh, and there's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
