A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. I'm so excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Ok, so reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne, like up to 87% less acne in young people. Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles. So having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? And are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
Ok, so if everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

I mean, climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do, right?

And you can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Ok, so most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better, right?
Q11: Ok, so veggies and fruits have these helpful plant things that are good for our brains and make them work well. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra bits each week, can already boost our mood and make us feel happier. There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Ok, so animal farming is like responsible for 80% of the amazon rainforest loss, coz they need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if there were no trees left here!But if we eat less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without much change. And if you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

You could challenge yourself, your mates, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is why 80% of the Amazon rainforest is gone, cos farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if there were no trees left here! But, if we eat less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without changing much. If you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hey there! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I‚Äôll be exploring healthy and sustainable eating with you. üòä

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I‚Äôll be sharing lots of interesting science facts and giving you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üëç
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing the meat we eat can save a lot of CO2, you know, the stuff that causes climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back! With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let‚Äôs start small; for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch. Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle. It's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. I like seeing how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I like seeing new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really improve acne ‚Äì up to 87% less in young people. Eating lots of vegetables and fruits keeps skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?
Q9: If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change. Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do. You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. That is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Veggies and fruits got like helpful plant stuff that help our brain work good. Just add some more veggies, like three more each week, it can boost our mood and make us feel happy. No limit to how many plants we can eat, it's all good for our brains! You could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days, with a cheat day here and there.
Q12: Well, animal farming is like responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest cause farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here! But if we eat less meat, like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hey there! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! So over the next two weeks, we're gonna explore healthy and sustainable eating together. üç¥üåç

About a year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and man, I learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan, you know? But being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet. üí™üå±

So stay tuned, 'cause I‚Äôll be sharing lots of interesting science facts and giving you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üí°üåü
Q2: Fruits and veggies are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3:
Reducing our meat eating can save loads of CO2, which is a big deal for climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China... and back!

With small changes like this, each and every one of us can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let‚Äôs start small; for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4:
More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. Its like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.

Factory farms keep going because we buy their products. But by choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is so so important for our stomachs, it's in plants, not animal stuff. When we get enough of it, we feel full and have more energy at school, no more tired feeling after lunch. Changing what we eat can be tough, but let's try plant-based lunches, it's an easy start to feel more energetic for the afternoon.
Q6:
80% of young people believe that living sustainably is so so important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.

I love how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each and every one of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. I'm so excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favorite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I really really love how new plant-based products and restaurants are appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Cutting down on meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really really help with acne, like up to 87% less for young people. Eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If each and every one of us ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that cant go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Veggies and fruits have these amazing plant things that help our brain be healthy and work really well. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra servings each week, can boost our mood and make us feel so so happy. There's no limit to how many plants we can eat, its all good for our brains! You could start by challenging yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is why the Amazon rainforest is disappearing, it's responsible for like 80% of the loss, all because farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Just imagine if there were no trees left here!But by eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without having to change much. Plus, if you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.
